poem:
**Discreet Divides**

In Italy, love sidesteps  
laws, two women—  
clinic whispers,  
a future suspended  
in the hands  
of uncertain approval.  
Embryos hold quiet dreams  
while society  
tilts its gaze  
past their delicate rebellion,  
unseen,  
yet fierce in the tender  
tug for life.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "My queer friends in Italy are so worn down by discrimination, they don’t notice it. Here's why | Viola Di Grado I was chatting online the other day with a female friend who is undergoing IVF in Italy to have a child with her girlfriend. IVF for lesbian couples is not approved by law in Italy; instead, doctors have the power to decide whether to approve the treatment on a case-by-case basis. My friend was". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
